summary: Paul Merson reignited his public debate with Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted in the 83rd minute during Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, stating that if Townsend could be selected, it would open the door for anyone else. However, Merson was proven wrong when Townsend scored a stunning equalizer for England against Italy. Merson admitted his mistake and praised Townsend's goal, while Townsend responded on Twitter, referencing Merson's earlier comments. Despite any prior tension, Merson continued to comment on Townsend's late substitution for Tottenham.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who would become the first Japanese player to represent the club if the transfer is completed. Muto, who has 11 caps for Japan and graduated from university with an economics degree, is currently on loan to Vitesse Arnhem if the move happens. The deal is not connected to Chelsea's sponsorship with Yokohama Rubber, and while Muto is honored by the offer, he has not yet decided on his future.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, published in Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics might contribute to childhood obesity by altering gut bacteria, potentially increasing food absorption and appetite. The study observed over 12,000 children, noting that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two, with repeated antibiotic use before age two raising the odds of being overweight. Boys appeared more prone to weight gain after antibiotic use and were slightly taller than those who hadn't taken the drugs. The study did not prove causation but highlighted concerns about the overuse of antibiotics in infancy and its potential role in the global childhood obesity epidemic. The research also points to the need for judicious use of antibiotics, as their overuse is linked to other health issues like eczema and digestive problems, as well as the growing threat of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, captured on camera by tourist David Meadwell, showed the soldier losing his footing, knocking his bearskin helmet, and dropping his rifle. The guard quickly got up, but was visibly embarrassed upon realizing how many people had seen the mishap. It is believed the slip occurred due to the metal protectors on his boots. The Queen's Guard, though often seen as ceremonial, are fully operational soldiers. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The original "Roots" miniseries, which aired in 1977 and reached over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E, Lifetime, and History for a 2016 simulcast. The new version will be more original and contemporary, drawing from Alex Haley's novel and consulting scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The new series aims to introduce the powerful story of Kunta Kinte to a new generation, against a backdrop of recent events in American history related to race and equality.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that palace aides at Clarence House in 1978 attempted to force him into an orgy. On his first day, he was accosted in a bedroom, subjected to inappropriate behavior, and threatened afterward. He left the job the same day and was ignored when he made a complaint. Decades later, after inquiries into a VIP paedophile ring, he contacted the Palace again but was initially rebuffed. Months later, his complaint was passed to the police. A retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement, citing he was working elsewhere at the time. The Palace has stated it will cooperate with the ongoing police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the video, they humorously recount their journey to parenthood and reveal a sonogram of their unborn child. The idea was to share the news with distant loved ones. The couple expressed surprise at the video's popularity and mentioned the possibility of making another video after discovering the child's gender. Melissa had previously made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy, which he learned about from a tag on their dog. A Pennsylvania couple had also used the same theme song for a pregnancy announcement the previous year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and full skirt, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in key scenes, including Scarlett’s encounter with Rhett Butler (played by Clark Gable) and an attack in a shanty town. The piece was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film, amassed by James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios makeup department head. Tumblin, who spent his life promoting Hollywood memorabilia, acquired the dress for $20 after it was nearly discarded. Other auction highlights included a $52,500 straw hat worn by Leigh, a $55,000 suit worn by Gable, and a $30,000 black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary in 2014. Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the edge. He slipped and fell 10 to 12 feet into the pit but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. The boy sustained minor bumps and bruises and was hospitalized in stable condition. He was not attacked by the cheetahs, who appeared frightened and did not approach the family. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the mother. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, previously used to enforce a 30mph speed limit, was turned off in March 2013 along with around 300 other fixed devices due to outdated technology. Speed enforcement has since shifted to mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Recently, the non-functioning camera was re-angled to point directly at a house on Wellington Road, raising concerns. Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and may remove the camera. They have no plans to include it in a new digital technology pilot for speed enforcement. The house owners were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. The six-time Olympic gold medalist expressed his readiness and enthusiasm for the event, highlighting Jamaica's strong relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed excitement about Bolt's participation, anticipating a standout performance. The full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona's basketball team by attending an El Clasico Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Despite this win, Real Madrid remains top of their division by points difference. Neymar also helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 in a challenging match and will return with his Barcelona teammates to La Liga to face Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrant arrivals from Africa and the Middle East, with 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday. The Italian coast guard received 20 distress calls on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, but the coast guard has not confirmed the incident. There has been an increase in migrant crossings and rescues in the Mediterranean, with most migrants coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria. Over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and at least 480 have died crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, although he is unsure of the exact reason behind the Chilean forward's decision. Sanchez has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage in the Luis Suarez transfer negotiations. He praises Sanchez's qualities and ability to revitalise the team. Wenger also downplays speculation about a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Brendan Rodgers for his work in developing Liverpool's team.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner will try to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, aiming to add to his achievements. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian rider Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career, is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. The event will be open to a crowd of 6,000 and will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Tickets for the event will go on sale on April 19.

Serena Williams, the world No 1 and twice French Open champion, described her challenging Fed Cup victory over Sara Errani as an "eye-opener," indicating she is less prepared for the claycourt season than anticipated. Despite her win, the US team was defeated 3-2 and relegated to World Group II after a doubles loss. Williams acknowledged her need to adjust her game from the hard court style to clay and emphasized the importance of being ready for extended rallies. The defeat in the doubles rubber marked a rare blemish on her otherwise perfect Fed Cup record. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez expressed hope for a stronger performance in the future, citing the team's strong talent pool.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, who previously spent eight years with the club before moving to Porto in 2009. Despite his struggles at Manchester United—scoring only four Premier League goals during his loan spell—the club's vice president stated that "the doors are open" for Falcao to return. Falcao, who scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his earlier stint, has recently shown good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country’s all-time goalscoring record. However, the potential move is complicated, as it remains uncertain whether Manchester United will keep him or send him back to Monaco, his parent club.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old pop star and X Factor finalist, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in a series of stylish images against a blurred city background, showcasing various hairstyles and outfits. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, noting that she regularly uses the product. Her manager, Mark Hargreaves, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and the brand, anticipating a successful partnership in 2015.

A man named Aaron Siler was shot and killed by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, after a chase and foot pursuit. Siler had an active felony probation and parole warrant. Torres is currently on leave while an investigation into the shooting takes place. In response to the incident, the Kenosha Professional Police Association erected a billboard featuring Torres and his dog, thanking the community for its support. Siler's family and friends, however, found the billboard to be disrespectful and are asking for it to be taken down. The police association stated that no offense was intended and that the billboard was meant to express gratitude for the community's support. Siler's shooting occurred just 10 days after Torres shot and wounded another man, Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. The shooting of Knight was deemed justified by the district attorney. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan, according to Iranian state media. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces, and the surviving assailants are believed to have fled to Pakistan. A militant group called Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group based in Pakistan's Balochistan province, claimed responsibility for the attack. The group has previously targeted Iranian border guards and seeks to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian authorities have asked Pakistan to capture the surviving militants, and the Pakistani government condemned the attack, stating that it is investigating and vowing to bring any militants who entered Pakistan to justice.

The passage discusses how Japan's Defense Minister, Gen Nakatani, confirmed in a parliamentary session that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO. This response was in reply to a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler-turned-lawmaker, who is known for his flamboyant personality and various endeavors in politics, wrestling, and entertainment. Inoki, who claims to have seen a UFO, asked about the possibility of extraterrestrial threats and ongoing research into alien visitors. The passage also notes that this is not the first time Japanese politicians have considered the implications of extraterrestrial life, with previous discussions dating back to 2007.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet while squatting on it at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He avoided sitting on the toilet seat due to concerns about cleanliness. The toilet collapsed, causing him injuries that required multiple stitches. Initially, he told his companions he was squatting, but later claimed to the police he was sitting to potentially avoid liability. Authorities consider the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom, which police traced back to him. Rebbie is accused of sexually abusing the girl from ages 9 to 13 and filming her and others with the hidden camera over a four-year period. Investigators found 41 videos, including 34 showing victims showering, some with close-up images of children's genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims and specifically purchased the camera to record the girl while she undressed and showered. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. Rebbie’s preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and he is being held on $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama created a series of portraits featuring fathers leaping dramatically in the air while their daughters stand po-faced and smiling next to them. The images, part of a book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," showcase fathers in sharp suits posing energetically, often with expressions ranging from joyful to pained. The daughters wear casual clothing, and the photos are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. The series aims to let fathers express their fun side, portraying them as "heroes jumping the sky" full of excitement and hope. The photos have generated significant online interest due to their unique and curious nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has shifted attention to the county championship season, particularly as Kevin Pietersen prepares for a potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed in 2014, looks to regain his place in the international set-up after being excluded from the disastrous 2013-14 Ashes tour. Rejoining Surrey, he aims to showcase his form to earn a spot in the Test team for the upcoming Ashes series on home soil.

Romanian football club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, sacked their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Despite being reinstated after initial dismissal due to poor performance, he was fired again following a 2-0 loss, which left the team 16th in the standings. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international, was replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao, who was loaned to Manchester United from Monaco, has struggled to perform at his previous level since joining the club, partly due to a past knee injury. Despite scoring only four goals this season, United may still pay £46 million to make the transfer permanent, though it seems unlikely. Nabil Dirar, Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao might regret the move, as he was not happy in France and could have had more success staying at Monaco, including playing in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The suspect, described as very tall and wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till and up to $1,500 in cash on Saturday. The robbery occurred at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch, where the offender demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter. Police were called at about 12:30 pm and confirmed there were no signs of weapons used. The suspect remains at large, and authorities are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. First, she was arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. A few days later, on March 24, another student accused her of having sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again on Monday, released on a $50,000 bail, and is yet to plead to the second set of charges. The Irving school district confirmed they took immediate and appropriate action, preventing her from working with students or being present on school property.

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws was viewed over 500,000 times online. The incident, witnessed by tourist Tim Weston, occurred near a local bike shop and a nearby crocodile sanctuary. The crocodile was seen holding the dog for hours before it disappeared. While social media users expressed horror, crocodiles are a common sight in the area due to the region's mangroves and urbanization.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which left them two points above the relegation zone. Bruce initially aimed for 10 wins to ensure survival, but with only six wins so far, he now hopes that eight or nine might be enough. Hull's upcoming fixtures include challenging matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries affecting key players such as Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them up to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman faced issues when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty against team rules, prompting a team discussion.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed and made changes to pupils' SATs exam answers at Mitton Manor Primary School, which invalidated the entire school's results. The changes were made outside of exam conditions, violating exam rules. An investigation by the local education authority confirmed the breach, leading to the Department for Education annulling all the school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick admitted to the allegations, claiming he wanted to make the answers more legible, but the panel found his actions to be dishonest and unacceptable. Although his behavior was not deemed fraudulent, it was considered a serious breach of professional conduct. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's goalkeeper, has not played much since joining in 2010 but is happy off the pitch with his wife, Misse Beqiri. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son. They have been dating since 2012. Lindegaard has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Beqiri is a Swedish model with Albanian roots who regularly shares her work and personal life on Instagram.

The glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction. The 13 letters, expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, received only one bid of $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The current owner, Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who attended the auction, bought the letters "on a lark" and joked about their size. He had promised to visit the winner's home if the letters were bought by a U.S. bidder. The auction also featured a New York Mets bullpen car, which sold for $112,500, significantly exceeding its estimated value.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after they were photographed inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha. While neither player will face disciplinary action, Rodgers emphasized the importance of conduct for elite athletes and the public perception that comes with their role. Rodgers is focused on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final of his tenure, despite past setbacks in title and cup competitions. He also mentioned the return of Steven Gerrard from suspension but did not confirm if he would start against Aston Villa.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a relaxed moment with his dog, captioning it "Home Sweet Home." Ozil performed well in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia. He is set to return to action for Arsenal against Liverpool after missing a previous game due to illness. Despite rumors of him being at a Berlin nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger denied the claims. Ozil has contributed significantly since his injury return, with four assists and three goals since January. He is adjusting well to English football, appreciating the busy schedule despite its demands.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has denied rumors of replacing manager Luis Enrique, stating the club is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title and has impressed with his work, particularly ahead of key matches. Bartomeu emphasized that there is no immediate plan to discuss Enrique's contract beyond its 2016 expiration, noting Barcelona's strong position in the race for three major trophies. Recently, Enrique's team defeated Valencia 2-0 with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson is set to sign a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth around £100,000-a-week, extending until 2020. This comes after he provided a lift for the club following their FA Cup semi-final defeat. Henderson, 24, is the third major player under Brendan Rodgers to agree to a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is considered for the club captain role when Steven Gerrard departs this summer. Meanwhile, talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume in the summer, though he has currently rejected a new deal.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea full back, has expressed his desire to remain at the club until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. Despite challenges in securing the left back position at Chelsea, Luis stated he is happy at the club. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is emphasizing the need for continued focus as the team aims to win the Premier League title, with nine challenging games remaining in the season.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal after significant backlash. Initially ruled "reckless" for a knee collision during a try, Hughes received a red card and suspension. However, the appeal, supported by strong criticism of the original decision, was successful, with the panel concluding the incident was accidental. George North, who suffered his third head injury in two months, was advised to take a month off. Despite being cleared to return, Hughes is not immediately in the match-day squad for Wasps.

The passage describes how a series of wildfires in southeastern Siberia, initially caused by farmers burning grass and fueled by strong winds, led to dramatic red sunsets in the Pacific Northwest, including Seattle. The smoke from the fires was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean, creating an amber-colored haze. The intense red color of the sunsets is due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange to dominate. As the smoke dissipates, the air quality will improve, and the vivid red sunsets will subside.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway just over a month after purchasing it. The car was later found and returned to her with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the car thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. While the car was returned with some changes, it also had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, which Schoenig is addressing by getting it professionally cleaned. Additionally, she is creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor Mick Sexton, the man who located her car and notified the police.

Manchester City players face a loss of £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. Key players like Sergio Aguero and Yaya Toure are on incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. A Champions League spot is crucial as the top three Premier League teams qualify automatically, while fourth place requires a qualifying round. City, currently fourth, have £12 million in bonuses at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged poor performance in the last three months, impacting their chances. They now face competition with Manchester United for top talent like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane. Callum Gribbin was the matchwinner for United with a free-kick. The match was attended by around 1,000 fans, and most of the players were English, with 10 from Manchester. Marcus Wood and Marcus Rashford had chances for City and United, respectively. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson came close to scoring again for United, and Javairo Dilrosun had a late chance for City. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have now lost both matches in the play-off series. The match highlighted the skill and commitment of young players who may deserve first-team opportunities in the future.

Joe Hart, an England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who recently received his 50th cap, expressed admiration for Buffon's career and stated that he looks up to him as an inspiration. Hart is eager to continue playing for his club and country, aiming to increase his international caps.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer burrito delivery in 67 cities. The service will include a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. Previously, Chipotle had rejected other delivery service offers but has now approved Postmates. The app uses independent contractors, similar to Uber. Chipotle's recent popularity has drawn celebrity customers, including presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other fast-food chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services. Starbucks plans to deliver coffee in Seattle and New York, while Taco Bell is testing delivery, McDonald's is planning "McDelivery," and Burger King has a pilot program in select areas.

The parents of Martin Richard, an 8-year-old victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 charges related to the attacks. They argue that pursuing the death penalty will prolong their family's anguish through years of appeals and reliving the trauma. Instead, they support a life sentence without the possibility of release in exchange for waiving all appeals. The Richards, who also lost part of their family when their daughter was severely injured, emphasize that they are speaking only for themselves and stress the need to move forward and heal for their family, Boston, and the country. The sentencing phase for Tsarnaev is set to begin after this year's Boston Marathon and is expected to last four weeks.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8 has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing approximately £400 million over three years. The jet, which typically carries 600 passengers, is now tailored for the owner and can accommodate dozens of guests. It features multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a master bedroom with a large bed and relaxation areas, a conference room, an office/guest bedroom, a restaurant, and an aeroloft with eight beds. The interior, designed to resemble a luxury hotel, includes plush accommodations, private chef facilities, and entertainment spaces.

SpaceX launched an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft on a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral to deliver supplies to the International Space Station. While the launch was successful, the attempt to land the rocket on a floating barge failed, as the rocket landed too hard and tipped over. This was the second attempt for the mission, as the first was scrubbed due to weather. SpaceX aims to land rockets to reduce costs by reusing them, similar to airplanes. The Dragon will dock with the space station to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies and later return with experiments and trash before splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the space station.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, which is located at the Westgate Hotel. She partnered with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for one Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding.' The winning couple will get married at the chapel on April 23, receive a free wedding reception and hotel suite for two nights, along with airfares and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. The chapel is part of a permanent Graceland exhibit outside Elvis's home in Memphis and will not feature impersonators. Couples must submit a video or photos and an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Henderson and Simon Mignolet each played their 47th game of the season, tying the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Henderson expressed confidence in Liverpool's ability to close the four-point gap on Manchester City, despite recent setbacks. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen both scored in the match, with Allen netting his first Anfield goal. Allen also commented on a controversial penalty decision during the game.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute from a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made key saves in the second half to secure the win. The result moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio in second place, while Napoli extended their winless run to five matches. The match, held under tight security due to past tensions, was free of incidents. Roma played without injured key players Francesco Totti and Gervinho, but Pjanic and De Sanctis were instrumental in the win.

Doncaster Rovers had a dull and uneventful League One match against Fleetwood Town, resulting in a 0-0 draw. The game failed to engage even the most dedicated fans, leaving the club's media team struggling to create meaningful highlights. They ended up producing a 27-second video containing just 14 seconds of match action, featuring the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle. The match took place at the Keepmoat Stadium with managers present on the touchline.

Roland Giroux has formed a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan in 1986. Despite the fish initially swimming away, it returns to be massaged and stroked by Giroux, who interacts with it daily for at least 15 minutes. The fish, which used to be bullied by two other fish in the tank, now enjoys being fed by hand and playing with Giroux, showing signs of frustration if ignored. Giroux documents their interactions on his YouTube channel.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character in the England cricket team, has had a challenging year with both highs and lows. His aggression, showcased in past incidents like punching a locker and clashing with Marlon Samuels, needs to be channeled appropriately. England coach Peter Moores has worked with Stokes to manage his behavior, ensuring his exuberance doesn't lead to being pigeon-holed. England wants to maximize his potential, balancing his feisty nature with controlled aggression to produce results in runs and wickets. The team also aims to integrate Stokes and Chris Jordan into the international game, as they believe both will continue to improve and contribute to the team's success.

The passage discusses the sell-out of 33,000 tickets for Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier match against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12. Both teams are tied at the top of Group B with 11 points, with Belgium in first due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has raised hopes of qualifying for the 2016 finals in France. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, the team prefers the Cardiff City Stadium, and UEFA rules prevent a venue change within 120 days of the match.

England's Under-17 team, the Young Lions, has been selected for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. As defending champions, they have a 100% record in qualifiers and are placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. The team includes talented players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have returned after missing previous qualifiers. The Young Lions will open their campaign against Italy on May 7, followed by matches against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht prodigy Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly regarded talent who has also attracted attention from Arsenal and Barcelona. Despite rejecting a move to Barcelona's academy at 12 to focus on his studies, Patoulidis continues to impress. City have discussed a potential compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the young playmaker for the club's future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of 33-year-old transgender escort Vanessa Santillan, who was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. Santillan, a Mexican national, had been working as a transgender escort in London, Paris, and Miami. She was pronounced dead at the scene after sustaining injuries to her head and neck. The suspect has been bailed and must return for further questioning. Police are appealing to anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward and are investigating the circumstances surrounding her death. Santillan had expressed her love for London and Paris on social media in the weeks before her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has experienced seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to accuse her friend and housemate, Jamie, of stealing £207 that she had saved for a gravestone for her child, Daniel James. After a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, Dawn became emotional and left the show in tears. Jamie, who has a history of burglary, had sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft and blaming his girlfriend. Dawn expressed feelings of betrayal, as the money was meant to honor her child and show him love.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women, children, the ill, and elderly, with conflicting numbers reported (217 by an Iraqi official, 228 by a Peshmerga commander). Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though the motivation behind it remains unclear. Yazidis, a persecuted religious minority of Kurdish descent, faced severe violence from ISIS when it overtook northern Iraq last summer, including mass killings, displacement, and enslavement of women. The situation worsened in the town of Sinjar, where many Yazidis fled to the mountains or into Syria, suffering a humanitarian crisis. The international coalition responded with aid drops, rescues, and airstrikes targeting ISIS. The U.S. State Department estimates 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, making up less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane has had an outstanding season, breaking into Tottenham's first team and earning a place in England's national team under Roy Hodgson. He is nominated for both the PFA Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year awards, competing against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez. A new animation by Copa90, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", showcases some of his best goals and celebrations, including a long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on England debut. The video was released ahead of the PFA awards ceremony.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the manager of Liverpool despite a season with no trophies and a probable finish outside the top four. Carragher argues that Rodgers' future should not be decided by one game and believes the new players have not yet settled. Liverpool is seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City and likely to miss out on the Champions League. Carragher hopes Rodgers, the players, and staff will focus on next season to win a trophy and return to the top four. He emphasizes the importance of correct signings to make a significant difference. Additionally, Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, where he has coached in deprived areas. He aims to help young people in his community realize their goals and is committed to giving back to his hometown of Bootle in Liverpool.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage for a trip to Lanzarote. Airport security, described as "over-zealous" by James's father, conducted a pat-down and inspection of the child. Phil Hayward, the father, criticized the process as "ludicrous" and noted the family had to leave the toy behind to avoid missing their flight. After returning from their holiday, the family bought James a replacement toy gun from eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and stated their regulations are set by the government, which prohibits any items that resemble prohibited items, including replica or model guns.

A lonely man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, known as "Rich," has posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The 31-year-old describes himself as athletic, non-drinking, non-smoking, and successful, with an interest in the outdoors, sports, and vehicles. He lists requirements for his ideal partner, including being non-drinking and non-smoking, fit and attractive, reliable, honest, and good with her hands. The successful candidate would receive benefits such as a gym membership, a phone, and a company car. The advertisement also states that former partners should not apply, and "Rich" promises to consider all reasonable offers. The Daily Mail Australia attempted to contact the man but was unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke has received support from five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—as he seeks to implement changes aimed at increasing the number of home-grown players in club squads. Dyke's proposals include raising the minimum number of home-grown players from eight to 12 and redefining "home-grown" to require three years of training in England before the age of 18. The Premier League opposes the changes, but the former managers argue that the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level is a disadvantage for England's national team. They highlight the emergence of young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, emphasizing the need for opportunity to sustain England's football development and improve its international success.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to the show's latest addition, just ten minutes into the new episode. Fans are captivated by Ross Poldark's affection for his wife, despite the unrealistic timeline of Demelza's pregnancy, which jumps from announcement to giving birth in less than a blink of an eye. This fast-paced portrayal of pregnancy is reminiscent of a previous episode where another character went from pregnancy to childbirth between two episodes, drawing humorous comments from fans on social media.

Leicester City, currently bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety, have had a mini-revival with back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner. Manager Nigel Pearson urges the team to stay focused on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. He emphasizes that their future is in their own hands and warns against becoming overly optimistic, stressing the importance of maintaining their own run-in to survival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a new record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Her journey revealed that she visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than an endangered western gray whale. This raises questions about the genetic differentiation between the two species, as only about 150 western gray whales are believed to exist.

Residents on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, specifically near the Shiretoko Peninsula and the town of Rausu, awoke to an unexpected change in scenery as 1,000 feet of seabed was forced to the surface overnight. This newly emerged land, rising up to 50 feet above sea level, is believed to be the result of a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The landmass measures roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide. Local residents were unaware of any tremors or sounds indicating the movement, as the landmass appeared suddenly. Authorities do not believe the event is related to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in the Kathmandu Valley and do not expect the new land to expand further.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports of his potential departure from Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, expressing his happiness and commitment to the club. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match, Van der Wiel reiterated his love for PSG, the city, and his teammates, and stated he has no plans to leave. He also mentioned his desire to sign a new contract. However, with PSG linked to a potential transfer for Barcelona's Dani Alves, it remains uncertain whether Van der Wiel will have a choice in staying with the club.

Carlos Tevez, a former Manchester City striker, is seeking to leave Juventus, where he is currently playing, to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite his contract with Juventus running until 2016, Tevez has expressed a desire to leave this summer. Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici has stated that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus to finalize the move. Although Juventus is reluctant to lose their top scorer, they have accepted his decision and are looking for replacements. Tevez has previously played for Boca Juniors, joining their youth academy in 1996 and scoring 26 league goals in 76 appearances before moving to Corinthians in 2005. Argentina's national team manager, Tata Martino, supports Tevez's decision, emphasizing that his performance is the most important factor and that a move to Boca Juniors would not be a step down.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, ripped his trousers during a 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League quarter-final at the Allianz Arena. The win secured Bayern's place in the semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski (two goals). Despite Porto's initial 2-0 advantage from the first leg, Bayern dominated the match. Guardiola humorously remarked about needing new trousers for the next match after the incident.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Four individuals, including a 40-year-old man, a five-year-old boy, a 27-year-old woman, and a six-year-old girl, were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital and Ipswich Hospital due to various injuries. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or further assessment. Emergency crews rescued a trapped individual using hydraulic cutting gear. The affected highway section was closed, with diversions in place, and police expected the closure to last several hours.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

- The Premier League is in a critical stage as Arsenal, second in the league, host leaders Chelsea.
- Arsenal's Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch, which he showcased on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from *Knight Rider*.
- Ozil is set to start for Arsenal in the match, despite the team trailing Chelsea by 10 points with six games left.
- Jack Wilshere recently returned from injury and was on the bench in the FA Cup semi-final.
- Arsenal legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere has the potential to be the club's future but needs to overcome recurring fitness issues, similar to former player Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford, despite sending off three players from both teams this season. City captain Vincent Kompany was recently suspended after being sent off during an international match. Clattenburg, who has been controversial in the past, has only shown two red cards this Premier League season, both to United players. The match is significant as United currently lead City by a point in the league standings, and the result could determine who finishes second behind Chelsea. Clattenburg will be supported by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string," suggesting they assumed he would resign after being accused of domestic violence and hiding a criminal past. Katter, of Lebanese descent, claimed he faced racism from both major parties and sympathized with Gordon's situation. Gordon resigned from the Queensland Labor Party but remained in parliament as an independent, causing political instability. Katter's remarks drew criticism on social media for his terminology, which he later defended based on his personal experience of being targeted for his dark skin. He compared Gordon to other independent MPs who compromised their independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is challenging stereotypes and inspiring others through dance and motivational speaking. Despite facing bullying and being judged for her disability, Dayna uses videos to show that she is capable of doing the same things as others, just in a different way. Her goal is to change the representation of people with disabilities in media and to encourage people to look beyond her disability and see her as one of them. She has created multiple dance videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and now speaks at local schools to inspire others and turn negativity into positivity.

Orlando City, an MLS team, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid and struggling. Hernandez, a Mexican international, would appeal to Orlando's large Latin-American fanbase. While Orlando is interested, eight European clubs are also keen on him, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United are open to selling him for around £8 million. Additionally, United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from clubs like Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting an initial offer.

A gang of at least three people attempted to carjack a man at a gas station in South Los Angeles, leading to an argument. When the man fled, the suspects poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger, which had two passengers inside, and set it on fire. No one was injured, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and surveillance footage is being used in the ongoing search for the suspects.

A chiropractor in southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. As part of an agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, he cannot apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances leading to the license revocation no longer exist. Despite these allegations, Manuel has received high patient satisfaction ratings, including a perfect five out of five stars on HealthGrades.com, based on three positive survey responses. Manuel, who no longer works at his former practice, also recommended that patients stop taking prescribed medication.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland, performing aggressive maneuvers that the U.S. deemed "unsafe and unprofessional." The U.S. denied a Russian claim that the plane's transponder was off and stated that the Pentagon and State Department would formally complain to Russia. This incident is similar to a previous one a year ago in the western Pacific, where a Russian jet flew dangerously close to a U.S. plane. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The thief is believed to have broken the car's window, used a rope and another vehicle's momentum to remove the rifle case, and left skid marks and pieces of rope at the scene. The rifle has not been recovered, while the agent's bags and clothing were found at a nearby hotel. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified before Obama's visit, but it is unclear if the theft prompted increased security. The motive and whether the car was specifically targeted remain unknown.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 in Canberra. During the trial, it was revealed that Costa may have been suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state was compromised, with evidence of confusion and fluctuating moods. The jury's decision hinges on whether Costa's unstable mental condition can be proven, as it could result in a not guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty against Burnley instead of experienced penalty taker Leighton Baines, who has a strong record in the Premier League. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but Everton still won the match 1-0 thanks to a goal from Kevin Mirallas. Martinez stated that multiple players can take penalties depending on their confidence in the moment, and praised Barkley for taking responsibility in a key moment.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line cruise ship ms Ryndam, with the cruise line indicating the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The incident was discovered by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door. The ship, which departed Tampa on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. Authorities, including the FBI, are investigating the case.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to a successful start in the 2018 World Cup qualifiers. The Caribbean island team advanced to the second qualifying round after defeating Montserrat with a 4-3 aggregate score. Curacao won 2-1 in the first leg and drew 2-2 in the second leg. They will now face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert's mother is from Curacao, and he has prior World Cup experience as a player in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, an experienced Argentine midfielder with a decorated career at clubs like River Plate, Real Madrid, and Inter Milan, believes keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. Despite Leicester's dire position, currently seven points from safety with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic and committed to helping the team avoid relegation. He joined Leicester on a one-year deal and has become a key player, expressing contentment with his time at the club and a desire for more points to secure their Premier League status.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her two young children by her mother, Debbie, due to her refusal to stop drinking, using legal highs, and partying. Gemma handed over her children to Debbie when they were four months old, and Debbie has raised them since. Debbie accuses Gemma of not being a responsible parent, stealing, and prioritizing her party lifestyle over her children and work. Gemma admits to stealing from her mother in the past, and Debbie is preparing to cut off Gemma's access to the children due to her lack of responsibility and trustworthiness.

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal after a challenge by Chelsea captain John Terry on United's Radamel Falcao. The Sky Sports pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's challenge, which involved an elbow to Falcao's head, was a foul and should have been penalized. Despite the goal being a notable moment, the pundits emphasized that the rough tackle on Falcao warranted a stoppage in play.

A tour bus carrying Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, causing the bus to stop and catch fire once everyone had exited. Scott and others on the bus, including her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were unharmed. The band's other members were not on the bus. Scott posted about the incident on Instagram, noting that only her Bible survived in the back lounge. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Texas.

A Scottish scientist, Dr. Adrian Quarterman, is exploring the use of space lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which can then be beamed back to Earth to power homes. The system involves satellites equipped with mirrors to harvest sunlight and convert it into laser light using semiconductors. While the technology could make solar power viable even in locations like Scotland and aid disaster recovery, the lasers will not be as powerful as those depicted in science fiction. Additionally, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges concerns about who controls the satellites. In a separate development, researchers in Tokyo have proposed using lasers on the International Space Station to clear small debris from Earth's orbit, though not for weaponization.

A convicted predatory paedophile, Stephen Munden, 54, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden has a documented history of sexual offences against children and was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He was described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, which was further evidenced by items found at his home, including children's clothes, books, and dolls. Munden, who has learning difficulties and is believed to be autistic, denied the offence, claiming it was accidental. A court was told he had admitted to ten unrelated offences involving indecent images of children. Police are urgently searching for him and have released images showing him both with and without a beard, as he may have shaved before disappearing.

V. Stiviano, the former companion of Donald Sterling, was ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts received from the former NBA team owner. These gifts included luxury items like cars and expensive personal items. Sterling's wife, Shelly, accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men, and the court decision allowed the Sterlings to recover the money spent on Stiviano. Donald Sterling's downfall was triggered by a leaked audio recording where he made racist remarks about African-Americans, leading to his ban from the NBA and the loss of his team.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players in the summer: a goalkeeper, a center back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker to improve their chances of winning the Premier League. He specifically questioned whether Arsenal can win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud scoring 14 league goals this season. Henry cited Chelsea's recent signings—Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fàbregas, and Diego Costa—as an example of how acquiring key players can lead to success. He emphasized the need for a competitive edge within the team to win the league.

A young woman who was abused by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn for years testified in court about the severe impact it had on her life. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The woman, who cannot be named, said she did not understand the abuse was wrong and only spoke out after learning Van Ryn had been caught. She expressed fear for her future relationships and the lasting effects of the abuse. She has suffered depression since age 14 and has been hospitalized for self-harm and attempted suicide. The court hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that has kept him out since March 2014. After missing most of the past year, he recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s and reported feeling "better and better." He is nearing a return to action and expressed optimism about his progress.

A young accountant, Jacob Phillips, 23, died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales. The incident occurred when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare after a night out with friends. Phillips and his friends had planned to use an ATM to get money for the fare but instead decided to run away, with Phillips running into the dark and over a fence. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, chased after him but stopped due to poor visibility. Phillips was found the next day by a dog walker on a rocky beach at the base of the cliff. An inquest recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the danger. Phillips worked for Pretty Green and had returned to Wales for Christmas.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay crisis did not receive compensation. Despite the passport agency making a £42 million profit, managers received bonuses of up to £3,500. Ministers refused to provide refunds to those who incurred extra costs or missed trips. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed surprise at the low number of compensation cases approved. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. The Passport Office made a surplus of £42.3 million and managers received a total of £1.8 million in bonuses. Some holidaymakers, like Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, were refused compensation despite losing money on trips due to passport delays.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, dating back to the 1930s, is up for sale with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro jars of food. The semi-detached property, untouched for over 80 years, includes the original bathroom, kitchen, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage cupboards. It has a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000 and will be auctioned on April 30. The house, while unimposing from the outside, boasts quirky interior features and is considered a paradise for collectors and antique lovers. Some upgrades, such as double glazing, have been made, but potential renovation costs may deter developers. The property is seen as a potential family home for those with a passion for antiques.

Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion, leading the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, though they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

The passage provides biographical information about Anne Rice, noting her birth in New Orleans and her later moves to Texas and San Francisco. It also describes Route 495, a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495, offering access to Midtown Manhattan via the Lincoln Tunnel.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Their debut album *Leisure* was released in 1991. Influenced by various music genres, Blur's self-titled debut album in 2001 achieved worldwide success. Albarn's solo debut album *Everyday Robots*, co-produced by Richard Russell and released in 2014, featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples from Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is home to many important national institutions.
The song "Happiness in Slavery" is by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails and is featured on their debut extended play (EP), *Broken*, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two different media adaptations featuring Bob Lee Swagger: a 2007 film where Swagger, a Force Recon veteran, is framed for murder by a private military company, and a TV series where Ryan Phillippe portrays an exiled marksman who returns to action to prevent an assassination plot against the president.
House, also known as House M.D., is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his group at his instruction. He also received convictions for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, commercial releases of his songs were made.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his career with a television appearance in 1974 and made his film debut in 1981. He gained critical acclaim for roles in crime dramas like *At Close Range* and *Carlito's Way*. He became a prominent leading actor with *Dead Man Walking* (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and a Best Actor award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn won two Academy Awards for Best Actor: in 2003 for *Mystic River* and in 2008 for *Milk*.

Sir Donald "Don" Bradman, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket through roles as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.

L.A. Reid has held high-level executive positions at several music labels, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He began his career in 1990 with the band Greta and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in August 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he was part of the band Prophets of Rage, which included members from Rage Against the Machine and other artists. The passage also mentions that Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The multi-camera series *The Millers* aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning two seasons and 34 episodes. CBS announced the show's cancellation on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas with her keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her feminism and sharp wit. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. The passage also mentions Ann Richards (October 1, 1935 – April 1, 1982), an American jazz singer and wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an independently produced EP titled *A Reminder* in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She also wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a key role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign, independent states free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have disappeared under mysterious conditions.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to a Super Bowl appearance that season, which they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In 2013, his first full season as starter, he helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal form of marketing communication used to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. It is distinct from personal selling and is delivered through mass media, such as traditional platforms (newspapers, TV, radio) and newer platforms (blogs, websites, text messages).
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts written by Noël Coward. It was also adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the UK's Prime Minister from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at around 17 or 18 and stayed until he was 37. After Plato's death, he left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the guitar pedal drum machine called BeatBuddy and is currently the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning a championship and the NBA Finals MVP in his rookie season and four more championships in the 1980s. After retiring for four years due to protests from players, he returned in 1996 at age 36 for 32 games before retiring for the final time. He has numerous business interests, was a part-owner of the Lakers, and was named one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine in 2009.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. The band has released three albums: *Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006), and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012). They first gained popularity in 1997 through their eponymous TV series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I, born on 19 June 1566 and died on 27 March 1625, was King of Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. Although he ruled both kingdoms in a personal union, they remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciaries, and laws. James advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland, achieving success in Scotland but facing significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as hits such as Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. The studio also produced the Netflix series Trollhunters, a computer-animated fantasy created by Guillermo del Toro in collaboration with Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017. He previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, he was ranked fifth in the world for super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh for middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush, born on July 8, 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her film roles in *John Tucker Must Die* (2006), *The Hitcher* (2007), and *The Narrows* (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and a major figure in global media. He is the father of James Murdoch, who is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. After the split of News Corporation on June 28, 2013, Murdoch maintained control over its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest-earning actress/model in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli, with most of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band that was active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified through an x-ray, which is a common radiographic examination.
The South Wales Coalfield, known in Welsh as Maes glo De Cymru, is a large coal-rich region in south Wales, particularly noted for its coal deposits in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when it was first held in 1962.

Mary of Teck became queen mother in 1936 when her son Edward ascended the throne, but Edward abdicated later that year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son, Albert, who became King George VI. She died in 1953 during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, before Elizabeth's coronation.
The film *Poseidon* earned $181,674,817 worldwide at the box office with a production budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton hold the record for the most wins, with three awards each.

Human trafficking involves the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), forced labor alone generated an estimated $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014. Of those affected, 14.2 million were exploited for labor (68%), 4.5 million for sexual exploitation (22%), and 2.2 million in state-imposed forced labor (10%).
The 2011 film *Rio* had a sequel titled *Rio 2*, which was released on April 11, 2014.

The passage discusses two individuals named Francis I. The first, Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany (1708-1765), had his real powers exercised by his wife. The second, King of France from 1515 to 1547, was the first monarch from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois. He was known as François au Grand Nez and the Roi-Chevalier for his personal involvement in wars against Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain. After unsuccessful efforts, Francis I formed a controversial Franco-Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a conflict between Francis I and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing, is a major Chinese research university and a member of the C9 League. It is the first modern national university in China, founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, replacing the ancient Taixue or Guozijian. Initially serving as China's highest education administration, PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his friendly mutton chops, distinctive gravelly voice, and unique bass playing style.

The passage highlights the effects of global warming on humans, specifically the threat to food security due to decreasing crop yields and the displacement of people as populated areas are abandoned because of rising sea levels.
Australia is a 2008 romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

The passage discusses Canadian folklore, which encompasses a variety of elements such as songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices like food-making and craft-making. It emphasizes that folklore includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 informative and entertaining propaganda and training films, and also trained combat cameramen.

The passage provides information about two individuals named James Jones. The first is James Jones, the author, who won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted for film and later as a TV series. The second is James Jones, the basketball player, who was a top high school performer, has won three NBA championships, and has notable achievements including reaching the NBA Finals multiple years and winning the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Humphrey Bogart as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images. *Trollhunters* is an American computer-animated fantasy TV series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
In 2009, Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE, which became effective on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in *Doctor Who* from 1974 to 1981, the longest tenure of any actor in the role. He also narrated the comedy series *Little Britain* and has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site includes a cleanup project, the Columbia Generating Station commercial nuclear power plant, and research facilities like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.
