Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to avoid a second election by forming a minority government, although Fianna Fáil will not support a full programme for government. A major issue in negotiations is the dispute over water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for their immediate removal and Fine Gael supporting their continued use. A commission to review the national water utility, Irish Water, is one proposed solution. Following the election, Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party seven, but no party has secured a majority, and TDs have yet to elect a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry, caught fire while traveling near Mallorca, forcing the evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. At least three people were injured, with one in serious condition. Rescue ships, including the ferry Puglia, assisted in evacuating those on life rafts, and the rescued individuals were being transported back to Palma de Mallorca. The cause of the fire was unknown, and officials warned that the ship may sink. Distress signals were sent at 13:50 local time, and psychologists were being deployed to support those affected.

The passage discusses concerns over duplicate voter registrations in the UK, with 38 MPs reporting cases of individuals, including students, potentially voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The Electoral Commission highlighted the need for better coordination between local electoral registers and the online registration system to identify duplicate entries. Despite these issues, a record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June election, with a 68.7% turnout—the highest since 1997. There was a surge in registration applications after the snap election was announced, with 2.9 million applications received over six weeks. However, the number of new registrations was significantly lower than the number of applications, indicating a high rate of duplicates. The lack of a direct link between local registers and the online service contributed to this issue, with duplicate applications estimated at 30% to 70% in various areas. The Electoral Commission recommended measures such as a verification function, similar to systems in Australia and New Zealand, to address the problem. Labour expressed concerns about making it harder for young people and students to register, emphasizing the importance of not discouraging increased voter participation. The Commission also called for individuals registered in two constituencies to choose one for future elections and stressed that voting twice in a general election is a serious offense.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL star from the 1990s, was found dead by suicide at age 40. He played for several NFL teams before his career ended in 1999 due to legal and behavioral issues. Phillips faced multiple legal troubles after his football career, including convictions for assault and served over 30 years in prison. While in prison, he was accused of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, for which a judge ruled there was enough evidence for a trial. His former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent but struggled with anger and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester after eight years of service. The promotion was awarded for "good behaviour" by Brigadier Andrew Williams. Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams, tracing back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th century. He joined the regiment in 2014 and has his own army number, receives payment for rations, and takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also participated in public events, such as switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

The passage describes a thrilling and dramatic match between Liverpool and Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, where Liverpool came back from a 2-0 deficit to win 4-3, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The match was played in front of an emotional and passionate Liverpool crowd at Anfield, under the leadership of manager Jurgen Klopp, who has transformed the team's spirit and performance. The victory showcased Liverpool's resilience and belief, echoing the famous 2005 Champions League Final comeback. The win moved Liverpool closer to the Champions League and highlighted key players like Divock Origi and Philippe Coutinho, while also pointing out defensive weaknesses that Klopp may address in the future. The match was celebrated for its intensity, atmosphere, and significance in the Klopp era at Liverpool.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Secretary of State for Exiting the EU, Mr. Davis, emphasized collaboration with devolved administrations (Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland) to secure the best EU exit deal for the UK, pledging monthly meetings to maintain a "two-way information flow." Meanwhile, Scottish Government Chief Secretary, Mr. Russell, called for greater transparency and clarity from the UK government regarding its post-Brexit strategy, particularly on EU market access and membership of the single market or customs union, which he deemed vital for Scotland's economy. The UK government also anticipates the High Court's ruling on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK's position in the appeal, with the Lord Advocate seeking to be heard in the case.

The passage discusses the ongoing health monitoring of a group of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones named Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane, who are genetically identical to Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. These sheep, living on a University of Nottingham farm, undergo extensive medical tests to assess their health and aging process. Dr. Sandra Corr and Prof. Kevin Sinclair are conducting these tests to determine whether the cloning process leads to premature aging or health issues. Dolly, who died at six-and-a-half from complications including osteoarthritis, raised concerns about the long-term health of cloned animals. The study focuses on three age-related conditions—cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis—to compare the cloned sheep with the general sheep population. The results, which will be published soon, could significantly impact the future of cloning. For now, the cloned sheep, some nearing their ninth or tenth birthdays, appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden let his unbeaten 4-7 favorite race and win by a length and three quarters. The horse will go to Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks where Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed's win in the Musidora brought a fifth win for Gosden and Dettori. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will walk the course before making a decision. Shutter Speed will prepare for the Chantilly race while Cracksman may not run in the Dante due to the short time before the Derby.

The passage discusses the fluctuations in the British pound's value against major currencies like the dollar and euro amid uncertainties surrounding the Brexit referendum. The Leave campaign claims the pound has merely returned to March levels, but investors are worried as the chances of a Remain vote have decreased, with polls showing the Leave camp gaining ground. Analysts predict increased volatility and uncertainty in the pound if the referendum race remains tight. Asian stock markets have also been affected, with significant declines in Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's main index. The London FTSE 100 initially had a muted reaction but ended the day down 1.1%. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argues that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters, as recent figures show a narrowed trade deficit.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just one point and one place away from the play-off spots. After a difficult match against Barrow, manager Cowley expressed mixed feelings, acknowledging the team's effort while noting the challenge of their part-time status and recent losing streak. Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the win. Despite the loss, Cowley remained optimistic, calling their progress so far "remarkable" and vowing to embrace the challenge ahead.

The passage discusses the shift in planning responsibilities in Northern Ireland, where local councils will take over decision-making from the Planning Service starting in April 2015. This move is seen by some, like Michael Corr, as an opportunity for local communities to shape their development plans. However, concerns are raised by groups like Friends of the Earth regarding potential unfairness and the influence of political donations on planning decisions. They advocate for transparency and a strict code of conduct to prevent a repeat of past issues involving discrimination and close ties between developers and political parties. The passage also touches on the debate around political donations and the need for greater transparency in Northern Ireland's political system.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which had to be amputated. Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and expressed concern about the danger in their housing estate, especially with children nearby. The Scottish SPCA and police are seeking information about the incident. Scottish SPCA Ch Supt Mike Flynn emphasized the need for urgent airgun licensing to prevent further harm. Last year, a Scottish government consultation on airgun licensing faced strong public opposition, with 87% of respondents rejecting the plan, calling it excessive. A small group believed the proposal did not go far enough. The charity is urging anyone with information to come forward.

Christian Benteke has signed with Liverpool on a long-term contract, making him the club's second most expensive signing. He joins as the Reds' seventh summer acquisition, following the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. Benteke, a Belgium international, previously scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. He aims to win trophies with Liverpool and expressed confidence in the manager's project. Liverpool struggled offensively last season after the departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, managing only three league goals from Mario Balotelli and Rickie Lambert. To address this, manager Brendan Rodgers added Benteke to strengthen the attack, along with Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to injury but returned to form, helping Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge both expressed confidence in Benteke's ability to succeed at Liverpool, emphasizing his physical presence and goal-scoring potential.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, examined the use of tablet devices in 671 state and independent schools, finding that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets to some extent. While there is no clear evidence of academic improvement, tablets are reported to motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement when taken home. The highest use was observed in academy schools. The number of tablets in schools is projected to nearly double between 2014 and 2016. Researchers could not definitively link tablet use to improved academic results but noted positive impacts reported by head teachers. A separate study highlighted the benefits of touch-screen computers for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. Many pupils use devices for social media and entertainment, and a significant proportion have access to tablets at home. Advocates, like Honywood Community School's head, argue for the importance of integrating technology in education to align with how pupils live and will work, despite the difficulty in measuring benefits in traditional metrics.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs showcasing the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images highlight both the joys and hardships of childhood, including special occasions and the reality of child labor. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, was carefully selected from the museum's extensive collections to reflect the evolving experiences of childhood over the decades. It runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals, possibly facing his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended by Micky Adams and has had previous spells with several clubs; his move is pending international clearance. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and noted Keating's youth and eagerness. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a new law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental permission, reflecting the country's poverty and economic needs. The legislation includes harsher penalties for child violence, such as a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Approved by Congress and signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, the law aims to address poverty and aligns with the reality of Bolivia, where over 500,000 children already work in various conditions. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) typically prohibits child labor under 15, it allows a minimum age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is currently evaluating whether the new law violates international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman, after experiencing symptoms like sudden nausea, aches, chest pain, and fever, researched "women's heart attack symptoms" online and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist. The doctor found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. She suffered a "widow maker" heart attack but did not call emergency services. Now, she warns others to recognize symptoms and call 911. She is known for acting in shows like Drop Dead Diva and previously hosted The Rosie Show, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was stabbed during a scuffle in an alleyway in Kenton on Saturday evening and later pronounced dead. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and hospitalized but is in stable condition. The incident occurred after a party on Belvedere Way, which was described as well-run with adult supervision. Che was not involved in an earlier altercation but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16, who were bailed. A 14-year-old was arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. Authorities are appealing for witnesses near the alleyway at the time of the stabbing.

The passage describes how Denmark reorganized its cancer diagnosis system to improve survival rates after poor performance compared to other European countries. The key changes included: 1) fast-track diagnosis for patients with clear cancer symptoms, 2) diagnosis centers for patients with unclear symptoms to quickly determine the cause, and 3) "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms to rule out serious conditions. These changes improved organization, reduced waiting times, and led to better survival rates without overburdening the system. The Danish model could offer lessons for Wales to improve cancer diagnosis and outcomes.

The UK government has disbanded the OFT, and Powys has won a contract to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents, receiving £170,000 annually. Complaints will still be handled by local trading standards, with cases referred to Powys if Estate Agents Act breaches are suspected. Powys aims to expand its role in the future.

The NHS Employers have approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce, allowing nurses and other healthcare professionals to take on additional roles with proper training, such as substituting for doctors and GPs. The Nuffield Trust highlighted the potential benefits of this approach, especially in addressing staff shortages and adapting to the shift in care from curing to managing long-term conditions. However, unions and medical professionals caution against using this as a quick fix, emphasizing the need for adequate training and funding. They argue that while expanding the roles of non-doctor staff is beneficial, it should not compromise the quality of medical training or be used to address chronic staffing issues without proper investment.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath following a crash at 03:00 GMT, disrupting traffic and bus services during rush hour. The closure was lifted by 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing into the cause of the collision. First, a transport company, reported that some services had returned to normal, but full service is expected to resume by the evening commute. Managing director James Freeman thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts during the incident.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the Swansea tidal lagoon project in Wales. The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the lagoon could result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying annually due to migration disruptions, based on the "best available evidence." Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the project developer, disputes these figures, claiming they lack a "clear scientific basis" and accusing NRW of refusing to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling suggests a worst-case fish mortality rate of 2%. The £1.3 billion project is seen as a test bed for larger tidal lagoon projects in Wales. While Wales' Environment Secretary supports the scheme, clarity is needed on the UK government's position, as it reviews the project's viability. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism, asserting that it has thoroughly assessed the evidence and followed a transparent process.

Northern Ireland plans to establish an industry-led agri-food marketing body, announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster. The initiative, modeled after Scotland's Food and Drink organization, aims to unite the agri-food sector—responsible for nearly 100,000 jobs—to enhance strategic marketing efforts and economic growth. The Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) will develop the body, which will coordinate government and private sector activities. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the move but notes potential implications for existing organizations and intends to collaborate with AFSB to address them.

The Woodland Trust has organized a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to participate in planting 40,000 native trees to commemorate the 40,000 people from Ireland who died in WW1. This initiative is part of a four-year project across the UK to plant millions of trees in memory of WW1 victims, under the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." The project aims to create a thriving habitat for wildlife and a space for people to reflect. Volunteers are encouraged to attend, wear appropriate footwear, and contribute to the effort, with saplings provided by the charity. The site is located about seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for *Someone Else's Skin*, praised for its emotional depth, tight writing, and exploration of domestic violence and honor crimes. The award was presented at the start of the Harrogate crime writing festival. Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, highlighted the strength of the shortlist. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career creating the character VI Warshawski, a pioneering female detective. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a broken finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a major setback for the team's qualification hopes. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to the team after the ICC Trophy in June, expressing his eagerness to make up for lost time. Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in a hit-and-run accident on a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, concluded it was an unlawful killing, citing circumstantial but overwhelming evidence. The car involved had stolen license plates and did not brake. Barry's wife, Ganna Ziuzina (known as Anna), was suspected of involvement, as she attempted to claim his assets shortly after his death. She was 19 years his junior and had an alleged affair with a Ukrainian man, according to the inquest. Barry's family believes the death was staged to gain his wealth, and Ziuzina sold his belongings and moved funds from his account. Despite Ukrainian police initially closing the case, it was reopened in 2011 as a murder inquiry but remains inactive.

Sophie Fearns stated that her son, Charlie from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle, America, for experimental T-Cell Therapy, which is unavailable in the UK. Charlie has been ill since age three and experienced a third relapse in April, leaving no treatment options in the UK. His first T-Cell transplant failed, and the family was heartbroken. An anonymous donor generously paid for Charlie's treatment, which came as a relief to the family. The Fearns received confirmation via email from the hospital, and Charlie now has financial clearance. The treatment will start as soon as possible, with the date expected to be confirmed next week.

Apple has introduced a two-factor authentication system to enhance the security of iCloud, following reports that third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. This security measure requires users to enter a four-digit code, either texted to a trusted mobile phone or sent via the Find My iPhone app, after entering their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store are blocked. Users can use a 14-character recovery key to regain access if their trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple had previously offered two-step verification, but it was not required for the back-up service. This allowed cyber-thieves to download complete back-ups of data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple's changes have made the back-up process more secure, but concerns remain about the recovery key being lost or stolen. Security experts recommend that two-factor authentication should be the default setting, rather than an opt-in choice, to better protect user data. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords to enhance security.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay FC are still being finalized. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant, is set to become a club director and has played for various non-league teams. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr. Ashley is being asked to give evidence about worker treatment following a BBC investigation into working conditions at his Derbyshire company. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has given Mr. Ashley until 21 March to respond to a letter requesting his attendance at a public meeting. The committee emphasized its commitment to transparency and noted that alternative dates have been offered, but Mr. Ashley has not accepted any. The committee warned of potential further action if he does not comply. Sports Direct has not commented on the issue but has previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," compiled by the colleagues of murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin. The report gathers facts from Russian and foreign media to argue that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for political gain. It claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in pro-Russian rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, contradicting Russia's claim that only "volunteers" are involved. The dossier presents evidence of Russian military involvement, including the role of Russian generals in directing battles and the financial cost of the conflict. Despite these findings, publishing the report was challenging due to fear and limited public interest, as many Russians accept the involvement if they believe it supports independence from Kiev. The report also highlights the lack of compensation for families of dead Russian soldiers and the difficulty of verifying evidence. The report's fate is uncertain, as previous similar works by Nemtsov failed to spark significant opposition.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearne in Rotherham, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire. He died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

The passage discusses tensions between the UK government and Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones regarding a letter sent by Prime Minister Theresa May about Article 50 and the return of powers post-Brexit. Jones expressed frustration over not being consulted on the letter's drafting, feeling disrespected by the UK government. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered by emphasizing the UK government's efforts to include Wales in discussions. While May's letter mentioned consulting on which powers should go to devolved administrations, it left unclear which specific powers would be devolved, such as farming or economic aid, and whether funding would accompany them. Jones is concerned about a lack of financial support after 2020, while some in the UK government question how EU funds have been used in Wales. Further details may come in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill, but the specifics of the devolution plan remain uncertain.

Two cars were damaged in an incident on Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay over the "mindless attacks" on PSNI officers and the local community. A PSNI Facebook post mentioned police were attacked while carrying out their duties and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was removed last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board stated in a court filing that they do not expect him to return. His lawyer claims the company's statements are false and accuses them of invading his privacy to gain leverage. The filing includes evidence of inappropriate emails and racially derogatory comments by Mr. Charney. The company argues that his actions violated their policies and that no company would risk hiring him. A restraining order has been granted against Mr. Charney, preventing him from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball game between Great Britain and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Earlier this month, Greece defeated Great Britain 92-64 in Patras, Greece. However, three Greek players will be missing in the upcoming match at the Copper Box, giving Great Britain a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box in London and emphasized the importance of the game in preparing for EuroBasket 2017. This game is Great Britain's only home game before EuroBasket, which starts in early September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. After playing against Greece, coach Joe Prunty's team will compete in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up games before EuroBasket.

The passage recounts the launch of the iPhone and its transformative impact on technology and society. Initially met with skepticism, the iPhone, unveiled by Steve Jobs in 2007, introduced a new era of mobile technology by integrating a user-friendly interface with powerful computing capabilities. The author reflects on the initial resistance to covering the product launch, comparing it to the significance of the Model T Ford. Over time, the iPhone revolutionized various industries, including photography, by enabling high-quality, portable, and instantly shareable digital experiences. The passage concludes by acknowledging the iPhone's role in beginning the mobile-connected era, paving the way for future innovations from companies like Amazon and Google.

A series of cat poisonings occurred in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, with tests confirming the animals had ingested a toxic substance, likely antifreeze. Seven-month-old cat Meereen died after showing symptoms and being taken to the vet. Three other cats died in the last seven days, and another died two weeks ago. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and urging residents to safely store chemicals and clean up antifreeze spills, especially during this time of year when it is commonly used in cars.

The passage discusses Greece's political and economic situation under the Syriza government, which is preparing to accept further austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors despite having previously opposed them. Despite this, there are no major protests in Athens, and Greece remains a popular tourist destination. The government is negotiating an €86 billion bailout, and while Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular, Greece is facing a severe economic squeeze, including monetary and fiscal austerity. The passage suggests that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors must show debt forgiveness rather than triumphalism.

The passage discusses Ross Kemp's return to the soap opera EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, will reprise his role to reunite the Mitchell family for Barbara's farewell. Barbara, portrayed by Dame Barbara, returned to the show after a 10-year absence to reveal her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in upcoming emotional episodes. Kemp expressed his excitement about reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time and highlighted Grant Mitchell's significance as one of EastEnders' most memorable characters. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins praised the opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden's talents in these episodes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, expressed their grief and guilt over not taking the threat seriously enough. Despite signs of the danger, they did not realize how serious the situation was. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court revealed Dhillon's obsession with Alice. In the aftermath, her parents founded the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to honor Alice's memory. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

EDF, a French company, approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, but the UK government has delayed a decision on the project. Critics are concerned about environmental damage, rising costs, and foreign involvement, as one-third of the cost is provided by Chinese investors. The delay has caused uncertainty and could impact the UK's energy supply and climate commitments. EDF has faced financial challenges, with a board member resigning due to financial risks. Environmentalists argue that the project is a poor investment and advocate for renewable energy instead. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and will require significant construction efforts. The UK government has postponed a decision, causing concern among industry leaders and investors.

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales includes a field asking for the name of the person with whom a spouse committed adultery. Although the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name the third party, family lawyers are concerned this may increase conflict and complicate proceedings. The form was updated to be more user-friendly, but the explicit question may encourage individuals to include the name of the third party, despite guidance stating it is "not normally necessary." Naming the person leads to them being part of the court case, potentially causing delays and increased costs. Adultery was cited in 12,148 divorces in 2015, and many clients want to involve the new partner, although judges generally disapprove of this. The Ministry emphasizes that naming the third party is optional.

The passage discusses the tension in Wales between environmental and commercial forestry interests. While the government promotes environmental policies favoring native, broadleaf trees and improved public access, the forestry industry, represented by Confor, argues that too much emphasis is being placed on the environment at the expense of timber production. Over 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001, and there is a need for significant replanting to meet demand. The industry contributes over £450m annually to the Welsh economy but faces challenges such as difficult access, transportation issues, and conflicts with local communities and conservationists. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social aspects through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and its Woodlands for Wales strategy. However, Martin Bishop of Confor criticizes the current system as overly bureaucratic and insufficient for meeting long-term targets, with only 90 hectares planted in the previous year compared to the needed 20,000 hectares.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge. Emergency crews responded to the incident on Bank Street at approximately 16:40, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with serious injuries.

The passage discusses the Arctic Convoys, a vital Allied effort during World War II where vessels transported supplies from Britain to northern Russia to support the Soviet Union against Germany on the Eastern Front. These convoys faced extreme conditions, including German U-boats, aircraft, cold, storms, and ice floes, resulting in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels by May 1945, and the deaths of over 3,000 Allied seamen. The Russian Embassy sought to honor veterans with the Medal of Ushakov, but the British Foreign Office initially refused due to rules prohibiting foreign medals for acts over five years old. After a campaign, an exception was made, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the medals in 2013. Veterans expressed humility, emphasizing their service as part of the broader war effort. Winston Churchill referred to the Arctic Convoys as the "worst journey on earth," highlighting the mission's extreme difficulty.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant delays in starting unpaid work sentences, known as "community payback," and noted that many offenders were not properly sanctioned for non-attendance. For example, one offender had completed only 16 hours of work in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice stated it was addressing the report's 15 recommendations. These unpaid work sentences, ranging from 40 to 300 hours, are assigned for various offenses and aim to provide a "tough" alternative to imprisonment. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do such work. Challenges include managing offenders with chaotic lives, enforcing attendance, and ensuring the work is meaningful. Inspectors praised some high-quality instances but stressed that unpaid work should not be seen merely as punishment. The report recommended better alignment of work with offenders' circumstances and improved enforcement. The Ministry of Justice emphasized the need for effective rehabilitation and acknowledged the report's findings, stating it was taking action to implement the recommendations.

The passage discusses comedian Alan Brand being criticized as a "hypocrite" by The Sun for advocating for economic and political revolution for the poor while living in a luxury home. Brand has faced similar accusations before, with viewers of his vlogs familiar with his spacious London home. During a protest, he was questioned about his own accommodation and became defensive, calling a journalist "a snide" and walking off. Newsbeat reached out to Brand about potential legal action against The Sun, but he did not respond. Brand has previously addressed the hypocrisy accusations, acknowledging his wealth and fame but emphasizing the need for personal and systemic change. He admits to past mistakes under capitalism and acknowledges the issue of economic disparity and ecological disaster. Brand believes the problem of hypocrisy can be resolved incrementally.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for his significant contributions to genomics and synthetic biology. Initially criticized for his competitive and unorthodox approach to mapping the human genome, Venter's methods accelerated the process and challenged scientific conventions. His work on the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae, and the formation of Celera Genomics, led to a race to decode the human genome, which was completed in 2001. Venter's wealth and independence from traditional funding sources enabled him to pursue ambitious projects, including the creation of the first synthetic life form, Synthia, by the J. Craig Venter Institute. Additionally, he has conducted extensive oceanic research to sequence marine microbes, aiming to enhance understanding of genetic evolution and function. Venter envisions synthetic microbes as a potential solution for environmental issues, such as reducing reliance on oil and capturing carbon dioxide. His career, marked by controversy and innovation, reflects a commitment to scientific urgency and transformative research.

The passage discusses a survey of around 1,000 parents in England regarding children's school lunches. Key findings include that 80% of children who ate school lunches tried new foods not eaten at home, and 50% of parents reported their children asked for school foods to be cooked at home. Popular vegetables included carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after concerns that some parents provided packed lunches due to children being fussy eaters. School meals are seen as a way to encourage children to try new foods and improve dietary variety. School meals in England now follow strict nutritional guidelines, and about 40% of primary school children eat school lunches, with a slightly lower rate in secondary schools. In contrast, about 46% of children in Scotland eat school lunches.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons at Real Madrid. His transfer included a buy-back option for Real, with a reported fee up to €30 million (£23 million). Morata has scored three goals for Spain and 27 for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He appeared in two consecutive Champions League finals, as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Morata began his career at Real Madrid, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but was released in May and is now without a team. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances during his second spell at the club, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is exiting the US market by transferring most of its loss-making Fresh & Easy stores to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Around 4,000 of the 5,000 employees will move with the business. Tesco will loan the new company £80m and may have the option to buy a stake if it becomes profitable. The disposal will cost Tesco £150m, with the remaining 50 Fresh & Easy stores expected to close. Fresh & Easy, which has operated 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007, has been unprofitable. This decision comes after Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The passage discusses the significant reduction in glacier coverage in the French Alps over the past four decades. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, glaciers in the region covered 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s, this had decreased to 275 sq km, representing an average loss of about 26%. Marie Gardent and her team from the University of Savoie conducted a new inventory using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual checks to ensure accuracy. The retreat is not uniform, with the southern Alps experiencing more significant losses than the northern Alps due to lower elevations and different climatic conditions. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also seen a slight reduction in size. Efforts to monitor glacier health continue across the Alpine region.

The passage discusses the Scotland women's national football team's progress in the qualifiers for the upcoming finals in the Netherlands. The team has won all five qualifiers so far and is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, with a victory likely securing their place. The team, led by Bayern Munich forward Evans, is determined not to miss out on a major competition after previous play-off losses. Iceland, currently ranked higher than Scotland, is also unbeaten in their qualifiers. The outcome of the match against Iceland and the return fixture in Reykjavik will likely decide the group's top spot. Evans, one of 12 players in the squad playing outside Scotland, highlights the benefits of having more players in top leagues, which helps the national team as they aim for their first major finals.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger based in Bath, was arrested in the west of England following a harassment complaint from a woman in south London. The alleged harassment, which occurred over a two-year period, involved some of his tweets. Campbell was released on bail and denied any threatening content, accusing the media of using innuendo to provoke speculation. The Metropolitan Police is investigating the online harassment allegation. Campbell has stated he will post less frequently on Twitter due to circumstances beyond his control.

Peta wants to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish named "A Happy Plaice" to promote an animal-friendly image for Skegness, criticizing the current mascot for implying animal cruelty in fishing practices. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, created in 1908, has become a well-known symbol of the resort. Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, acknowledges the suggestion but believes the mascot is widely loved and does not portray animal cruelty, expressing a preference to keep it unless there is significant support for change.

In a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia, Scotland dominated from the start after initially falling behind due to an early try by Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze. Tommy Seymour equalized for Scotland and the team went on a strong scoring run with tries from Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg, and Hamish Watson, giving Scotland a commanding lead. Georgia managed to score two tries, with a second one from Lobzhanidze, but Scotland continued to score, with Hogg adding another try and Ali Price and Rory Hughes contributing to the final points. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised the team's performance, particularly in the first half, and noted the challenges in the second half due to weather conditions.

Widnes secured a 38-26 victory over Castleford in a closely contested match. The first half saw tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, giving Widnes a 14-6 lead, with Paddy Flynn scoring for Castleford. In the second half, Flynn added another try, but Widnes responded with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (twice), and Joe Mellor, extending their lead to 38-12. Castleford fought back with three tries in four minutes from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick, but Widnes held on for the win. The Tigers' defense struggled, especially after Mellor's decisive try, and they suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat. The result moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, just one point ahead.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee at the US Guantanamo Bay facility since 2002, was released after a review panel concluded he was not a significant security threat. Arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—which he denies—he had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. His release, secured after a Kuwaiti government effort, was celebrated by his lawyer, who expressed joy over his return home. However, Mr. Odah must now spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti rehabilitation center. His release reduced the number of Guantanamo detainees to 148. This marked the first release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. President Obama has long sought to close the Guantanamo facility, opened in 2002 after the 9/11 attacks.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before a wreath-laying ceremony at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first Anzac Day commemoration in the UK was in 1916 when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey. Since then, these services have become significant for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor their countrymen's sacrifices in all wars. Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowd at the dawn service, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings and the courage of the Anzac troops. Veterans, service personnel, and their families took part in the parade, while crowds, including expats, lined the streets to watch the ceremony. The eight-month Gallipoli campaign was one of the bloodiest of the war and aimed to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, 30, has joined St Mirren for a second spell and could make his debut against Alloa in the Championship. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been training to stay match fit. Capped twice for Scotland in 2008, he has made nearly 400 senior appearances and previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of bottom side Alloa. Clarkson aims to help the team win games, gain confidence, and push up the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, with initial concerns about workers' pension schemes. Unite, the union, received assurances that existing agreements would be honored. The final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current members have an unaffected alternative scheme. Boparan confirmed that pension arrangements would continue under new ownership. Efforts to restore the business to profitability will include increased investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken alongside turkeys.

The passage discusses the issues surrounding a new chain ferry in Cowes, which has experienced breakdowns, groundings, and suspension due to training and technical problems since its launch on 14 May. Council leader Dave Stewart announced the crossing would be free until 2 July to address the problems and gather feedback. A review of the project is being conducted by auditors. Local businesses have been affected by the ferry's issues, and the possibility of compensation is being discussed. Transport councillor Ian Ward emphasized that the ferry is a prototype with expected teething problems and noted that some issues have been resolved.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the possibility of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a post-Brexit deal. The fishing regions, which voted heavily in favor of leaving the EU, are at risk of being marginalized in negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is seen as unfavorable by the UK fishing industry, which supported the Brexit campaign. Brexit is seen as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns of risks and opportunities for the UK industry, emphasizing the need for continued market access. The report also mentions the potential for EU member states to demand more access to UK waters in exchange for trade benefits. The CFP framework may lead to four different fisheries management regimes in the UK. Despite concerns, the industry remains optimistic about the opportunities Brexit may bring, with recent EU quota agreements seen as positive developments. The UK government aims to ensure fair access to quotas and sustainable fisheries management post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney admitted to possessing or allowing the taking of images of partially dressed young boys in erotic poses between 2004 and 2014. He received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to attend a sex offender program. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing found his actions incompatible with being a teacher, citing a long pattern of behavior and a high likelihood of recurrence due to the volume of images and lack of remedial action. Geaney was deemed unfit to teach, removed from the professional register, and barred from reapplying for two years. He was not present at the hearing.

A fire on 2 March at Duncan Street required firefighters to spend several days at the site, causing train disruptions and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire, revoking its environmental permit. The firm, operated by Asset and Land Group, was described as "broadly compliant" with fire safety law by the fire service. The fire service had raised concerns about potential risks to residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint inspections with EA staff. The permit revocation takes effect on 7 August unless appealed by the company, which will then be unable to operate at the site. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is striving to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite challenges such as attacks on shipments and missed deadlines. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad attributed delays to security issues and ongoing war, while denying accusations of using barrel bombs against civilians. Reports indicate significant casualties from such attacks in Aleppo. The Syrian government also denied rebel control over a central prison in Aleppo, while human rights groups provided conflicting accounts. The US expressed concern over the delayed progress, and Russia urged Syria to complete the transfer of weapons by 1 March. The OPCW acknowledged that security concerns have slowed the destruction process, but Syria claims commitment to fulfilling its obligations.

England secured a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. England's strong performance, including a remarkable 254 by Joe Root in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, contributed to their second-largest win against Pakistan in terms of runs. Root, promoted to number three, received praise from captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss for his controlled and responsible batting. England's dominance was evident on a pitch offering little assistance to the bowlers, while Pakistan struggled with confidence and shot selection. The series is expected to remain competitive, with the third Test set to begin on 3 August.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is gathering experiences from residents, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for improvement. Rochira emphasizes the importance of listening to older people and their caregivers to understand both positive and negative aspects of care. Her assessment includes factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's goals, it criticizes the absence of care providers on the advisory panel, which it believes hinders collaboration and engagement with the sector.

Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder, has been appointed as the new manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. He previously served as player-manager for Arbroath since 2010, leading them to their first national trophy in 2011 by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion. Despite Aberdeen's interest in retaining him, Arbroath chairman John Christison supported Sheerin's decision to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has a background playing for various Scottish clubs, including a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, and also played for Östersunds in Sweden before transitioning into coaching.

Swansea City has appointed interim manager Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams for the match against Bournemouth following the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club is in a difficult position and is seeking a new permanent manager, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and emphasizes the importance of the club's history, referencing its remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and relegation to becoming a well-run club known for possession-based football. Curtis also notes that the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and has struggled with consistent management and player replacements. He acknowledges the difficulty of being promoted back from the Championship, which has become stronger, if the club were to be relegated.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome by introducing a competitive approach, which earned him both acclaim and criticism from the scientific community. Known for his confidence and wealth, Venter's contributions to genomics were groundbreaking. After the human genome project, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in "Synthia," published in the journal Science. Venter's early life included a non-academic youth and a stint in the Vietnam War, which influenced his urgency and drive. His career shifted from medicine to molecular biology, where he pioneered rapid gene sequencing techniques and faced criticism for his unconventional methods. He founded the J Craig Venter Institute and other ventures, including oceanic genetic research and synthetic biology projects aimed at environmental solutions. His work has sparked both controversy and potential for significant industrial and environmental impact.

The Sutton Trust report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, highlights significant issues with the quality and structure of apprenticeships in England compared to countries like Germany. Many apprenticeships are low quality, too short, and below level three (equivalent to A-levels), with over half offered to those over 25. The report calls for the creation of 300,000 new apprenticeship starts annually, prioritizing level three and four courses. It emphasizes the need for a clear, respected vocational system to improve social mobility and economic competitiveness. While the Department for Education states it is reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, the Association of Colleges acknowledges challenges in expanding opportunities and preserving well-respected level two apprenticeships.

The passage highlights British athlete Sarah Storey, who recently won a time trial event in Nottwil, Switzerland, more than two minutes ahead of her closest competitor, Anna Harkowska. This victory brings her closer to a 17th title in Saturday's road race. At 37 years old, Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals—11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze—across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She won four gold medals at the 2012 London Games and has 21 world titles to her name. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before transitioning to cycling in 2005. She aims for further success at the upcoming Rio Paralympics.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to ongoing financial difficulties. Despite multiple deadline extensions to pay their £148,000 debt to football creditors, the club, now owned by Tommy Agombar, failed to meet the final deadline. Chester FC, who reformed after the 2010 expulsion of Chester City, have taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier following a dramatic final-day result. The Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for £1, but they were not the preferred option. The club's financial struggles have been worsened by a significant drop in attendance since their relegation from the Football League in 2012.

The passage discusses the career of a former Manchester City player, who is 30 years old. He earned 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009 and was part of England's squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. The player, who has also played for the England Under-21 team 46 times, scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He expressed a wish for success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for about 30 years across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was known for his 1980 recording of Handel's *Messiah*, which was celebrated as one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and held positions with renowned ensembles and institutions, including the Early Music Consort of London, Harvard University, and the University of Cambridge. Colleagues and peers described him as generous, a natural academic, and a key ambassador for historically informed music. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow.

A boy from Northern Ireland is struggling to access a special school as all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are full. His parents removed him from mainstream schooling in June, but he has yet to be placed in a special school. His mother expressed concerns about the isolation he is experiencing and the lack of capacity in the special needs school system. The family has been informed that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and there is hope that the boy will be able to start there soon. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland and aims to ensure availability close to where children reside, with this work ongoing to assist with placements from 2016.

Newport County have a lease to use Rodney Parade until 2023, and they are expecting the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) to honor this agreement as the WRU plans a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons, to be voted on on May 9. The WRU intends to make Rodney Parade a rugby venue and install an artificial surface, which conflicts with Football League rules. Newport County are currently in a strong position to avoid relegation from League Two. Losing their Football League status would be a significant setback for the club and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the journey of an individual from Sierra Leone who was kidnapped by rebels at age 15 during the civil war, forced into violence and drug use, and later escaped to rebuild his life with the help of a preacher. He became involved in community work and, during the 2014 Ebola crisis, helped educate people, provide support, and establish an Ebola treatment clinic, saving many lives. He emphasizes the importance of investing in youth to create a better future. The passage also provides statistics on Ebola deaths across several countries.

Approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum were at risk of being auctioned to help pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign launched in September successfully met its target within a month, allowing the collection to remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was finalized with the help of administrators Begbies Traynor, and the outcome was described as "fantastic news" by Tristram Hunt MP, who emphasized the collection's importance in charting Britain's cultural development and national identity.

The passage outlines potential developments at Billericay FC. Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a possible deal for Wright to purchase 20% of the club are not yet finalized, and The Sun reported that Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league footballer, could become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has expressed willingness to invest £10,000 weekly. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

In a closely contested match, Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took an early lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized shortly after from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from close range. The first half saw several near misses, including a brilliant save by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe to deny Colchester before halftime. In the second half, Blackpool had multiple chances to win, including a missed header by Tom Aldred from a corner. The game ended with Colchester playing with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The passage discusses the redevelopment plans for the disused Fawley power station, which closed in 2013. The developers, Fawley Waterside, intend to repurpose the site into a "merchant city" with a £1bn development, including a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The centerpiece of the project will be the existing 198-meter-tall chimney, making it the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. The power station, commissioned in 1971, was a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired station fueled by the nearby Esso refinery and powered one million homes. The developers plan to apply for outline planning permission later in the year, with construction potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong championships, Latham won a bronze medal in the men's individual pursuit, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. Latham overtook competitors in a final sprint, though Poland's Adrian Teklinski narrowly held onto gold. GB's men's team pursuit missed out on bronze to Italy. In the men's keirin, Joe Truman was outclassed in his semi-final, while the women's team pursuit finished fifth and failed to qualify for the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker joined a young, inexperienced team in the women's team pursuit, expressing optimism about their future potential. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, citing a lack of "zing" and the transition from the Olympics as possible factors. Marchant plans to compete in two more events before the competition concludes.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes to reunite the Mitchell family. Barbara's character, Peggy, returned to Albert Square after leaving in 2010 to reveal her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in emotional spring scenes. Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006, will return to bring the Mitchell brothers together for their mother's last moments. Grant Mitchell is an EastEnders legend, known for his dramatic storylines, and his return is expected to be a significant moment for the show. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins believes this is an opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Sadio Mane scored twice within 138 seconds as Liverpool defeated second-placed Tottenham at Anfield. Tottenham's manager, Pochettino, expressed concerns about the team's lack of desire and readiness to fight for the Premier League title. He warned that if Chelsea extend their lead to 12 points, it would be a significant challenge. Tottenham's poor away form includes only one win in their last 17 matches against top-six teams. Former player Danny Murphy criticized Tottenham's defensive strategy and mindset during the game, noting a need for quick improvement.

The APC won 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the PDP, which had been in power for 16 years. This is the biggest loss for the PDP since democratic rule began in 1999. The APC's Muhammadu Buhari will become president, defeating former President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline is evident in key northern states and Adamawa, but it retained control in the oil-rich Niger Delta and parts of the south-east. The APC did not win any of the five oil-producing states, which could affect the government's oil revenue. The elections saw some violence, particularly in the south, but were generally more peaceful than previous years. The PDP now faces a period of rebuilding, as voters sought change after allegations of corruption and ineffective handling of the Boko Haram insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19 to 22 July, will offer an app-based augmented reality experience for visitors to access online content such as videos, band interviews, and event information via signs and posters. The app allows users to access real-time updates, buy tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere, both on-site and globally. This year's lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

The passage discusses several schools in Birmingham, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, which have been rated inadequate by Ofsted. As a result, their funding agreements are at risk of termination. Park View Educational Trust may also be removed from running these schools. The schools were accused of promoting a narrow, faith-based ideology, not promoting the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils, and failing to address concerns. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools shared her experience of facing challenges from parents and feeling alone during the situation. Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted by a hardline Muslim takeover, with five of them being rated inadequate. Birmingham City Council plans to work with Saltley School to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash criticized the schools for their failures and outlined actions they must take to address the issues. Parents at the schools have criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after having a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal." Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution argues that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the eye test and did not refer him for further investigation, which ultimately led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increased pressure in his skull, and his death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg arranged meetings between a woman and a man he found on an adult website, filmed them having sex, and sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was found guilty of coercing the woman into sexual activity and distributing explicit material, despite denying the charges. Weatherhogg, 42, was placed on the sex offenders register and the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge emphasized that the sentence should reflect society's condemnation of his actions. The defense described the remand as a "dramatic shock" for Weatherhogg.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 no), and captain William Porterfield (39) contributing key runs. Afghanistan chased down the target for 171-4, with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) leading the charge, securing victory with two overs to spare. Ireland's opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck, causing an early setback, while Afghanistan's opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) helped them cruise to victory. Ireland's captain expressed disappointment at falling short of a higher score, and the absence of paceman Boyd Rankin due to injury added to their challenges. Rankin is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs against Afghanistan starting on 15 March.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar and claims they have not committed any tax-related crime in relation to the signing. The club made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend their reputation and good name. The case is still under investigation and it is uncertain if it will be dropped after the payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to collaborate with Thai authorities, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21. The suspects are alleged to have confessed to the murders and are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, facing a potential death penalty. UK detectives have completed their review of the investigation and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. The UK Foreign Office raised concerns about the verification of DNA samples and potential mistreatment of suspects. Post-mortem results show that David died from drowning and a head injury, while Hannah died from head wounds. DNA found on Hannah matches the suspects.

The Scottish women's national football team, having won all five qualifiers, is close to securing a place in the next major finals without needing a play-off. They face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with the match likely deciding the group's top team. Scotland's forward, Evans, emphasizes the team's determination to avoid a third consecutive near-miss after play-off losses in 2013 and for the 2023 World Cup. The team benefits from having 12 players playing abroad, including at top European clubs and in the U.S., enhancing the national team's performance. Evans highlights the positive impact of playing in competitive leagues and training with top players, contributing to the team's goal of reaching their first major finals.

Apple has introduced a two-factor authentication system for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access, particularly after reports that third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. The system requires an additional step after entering a username and password on a new device, including a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile number or via the Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases are blocked. Users can use a 14-character recovery key to regain access if their trusted device is lost or stolen. While Apple had offered this system before, it was not previously applied to its backup service. Apple's new changes address the security vulnerability exploited by Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which had been used by hackers. However, concerns remain about the recovery key being hard to remember and potentially stolen. Security experts recommend that two-factor authentication should be the default setting, not an opt-in feature, to better protect users. Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, emphasizing the importance of user awareness in security.

In the May election, UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour spent £1,027,339. The campaign period covered from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP spent 68p per vote, Labour 26p, the Conservatives 79p, and the Lib Dems £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP spent £267,372. Altogether, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals, potentially facing his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended by Micky Adams to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson and has had previous spells with several clubs. Anderson is described as a leader with limited game experience, while Keating is young and eager to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and later died after winning a race at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." While such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues, the racing community is determined to better understand and prevent these occurrences. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Despite his history of overheating, the report concludes that his death was due to the rare haemorrhage and not linked to his past condition.

The passage describes emotional and reflective farewell speeches by several Scottish politicians, including Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, who are all stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, in his valedictory address, reiterated his belief in Scotland's diversity and unity, and highlighted the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. He also expressed dissatisfaction with the Scotland Bill not fully meeting the promises made during the referendum campaign. McNeil emphasized the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster, particularly in terms of accountability and scrutiny. The passage also mentions Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, who is also leaving Holyrood.

The passage provides details about the live-action adaptation of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast." Emma Watson is cast as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. Josh Gad will play Gaston's sidekick, LeFou, while Kevin Kline portrays Maurice, Belle's father. A star will play Mrs. Potts, the teapot, a role previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May, with a planned US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecision Service (CPS) will meet with victims' relatives to announce decisions on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans died. New inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. Fifteen cases are part of the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes, and eight relate to a probe into the police's conduct. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall, who lost her son, have endured a long wait for accountability and remain determined to see justice.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, leading to concerns about contraband such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis entering the facility. A local resident reported witnessing this happen multiple times in two weeks. While the Ministry of Justice acknowledges staff efforts to prevent contraband, they admit more needs to be done and are working on providing prisons with better tools. The Ministry also noted that laws have been introduced to jail smugglers for up to two years, though there is no evidence of drones being used at Chelmsford Prison.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries when Brian Wright, 55, struck her while driving through a red light outside a school in Kempston last December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and does not recall the traffic light color; he has apologized for his actions and expressed remorse. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The case is ongoing, with the court considering whether the sun could have impaired Wright's vision. Mrs. Blackburn, who was on duty and wearing appropriate clothing, is now in residential care.

Laura Muir will not compete with the Scotland team at next year's Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies, as her exams are in May.
